text.headline: Christians in India after St Thomas
Troubles begin in the Mar Thoma Nasrani Church
Prexisting trade routes
text.text: The king Hiram of Tsur, the contemporary of Solomon (972-932 BC) promoted international trade with South Indian Coast. Spices like pepper, ginger, precious gems, ivory, gold, peacocks, apes etc. were exotic attractions from South India. The first Jewish colony of South India goes back to the days of King Solomon - (S. S. Koder, Kerala and her Jews, p2)

text.headline: Jesus' Death on the Cross
text.text: Then Jesus cried again with a loud voice and breathed his last. At that moment the curtain of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom. The earth shook, and the rocks were split. The tombs also were opened, and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised. After his resurrection they came out of the tombs and entered the holy city and appeared to many. 54 Now when the centurion and those with him, who were keeping watch over Jesus, saw the earthquake and what took place, they were terrified and said, “Truly this man was God’s Son! - (Matthew 27:50-54)

text.headline: Jesus' Ascension to Heaven
text.text: He replied, "It is not for you to know the times or periods that the Father has set by his own authority. But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you; and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth." When he had said this, as they were watching, he was lifted up, and a cloud took him out of their sight. - (Acts 1:7-9)

text.headline: Pentecost
text.text: And suddenly from heaven there came a sound like the rush of a violent wind, and it filled the entire house where they were sitting. Divided tongues, as of fire, appeared among them, and a tongue rested on each of them. All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages, as the Spirit gave them ability. - (Acts 2:2-4)

text.headline: St Thomas' Mission to South India
St Thomas' Mission to South India
Alexandrian scholar, Pantaenus, visits and testifies to the presence of Christians in Malabar.
Papa bar Aggai was consecrated as Bishop of Seleucia-Ctesiphon by two visiting bishops, Akha d'abuh' of Arbela and Hai-Beël of Susa
text.text: While Christianity had been introduced into Assyria then largely under the rule of the Parthian Empire in the first centuries AD, during the earliest period, leadership was unorganized and there was no established succession untill this point.

text.headline: First Council of Nicaea
text.text: The primary goal was to settle the theological dispute caused by Arianism, which claimed Jesus was a created being and not equal to God the Father. The council produced the Nicene Creed, which affirmed the divinity of Jesus and his co-equal status with God the Father. It also condemned Arianism and exiled Arius and some of his followers. Affirmed by The Church of The East

text.headline: Persion Migration
text.text: By this time, many Persian Christians started to flee the Sassanid terror. A good number of them came to Malabar for the rulers there were more tolerant... as well as the presence of a Christianity of the same patrimony accelerated this move. One such group was led by a merchant named Thomas of Cana. According to tradition, Thomas of Cana migrated to Muziris with a bishop and 345 East Syrian Christians from 72 families... The followers of Thomas of Cana, also known as Knayi Thomman, are today recognised as the Knanaya community. The Knanaya migration must be the pivotal point which brought an episcopal connection between the Indian and the Persian church. Since then, the Patriarch of Seleucia-Ctesiphon sent bishops to India regularly.

text.headline: Mar Aprem references India.
text.text: Mar Aprem is important to us in the Indian Church because his poems refer to the Apostle Thomas having become martyr in India. As evidence on the tradition of St. Thomas founding Church in India is being questioned by some doubting Thomases, St. Ephrem comes to bear testimony to the fact that the St. Thomas tradition is at least as old as the 4th century when Mar Aprem lived and wrote. How early was such tradition in vogue in the Middle East, is not known. - (Mar Aprem - Theologian & Poet SEERI, p11)

text.headline: First Council of Constantinople
text.text: The council affirmed the Nicene Creed, originally formulated in 325, and expanded it to clarify the relationship between the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, producing what is now known as the Niceno-Constantinopolitan Creed. The council definitively declared the Holy Spirit to be fully God, equal to the Father and the Son.

text.headline: The Church of the East received state recognition from the Sassanid Emperor Yazdegerd I
text.text: The Council of Seleucia-Ctesiphon was also called, at which the church's hierarchy was formalized.

text.headline: Council of Ephesus
text.text: The council ultimately condemned Nestorianism, affirmed Mary as the Theotokos (God-bearer), and defined the relationship between Christ's divine and human natures. Nestorius is condemned a heretic. The Church of The East refuses to condemn Nestorius. Modern discoveries of works written by Nestorius (The Bazaar of Heracleides) lends credence of The Church of The East's claims of Nestorius' orthodoxy and reveals that the issue lied within a conflict of two distinct schools of thought, antiochian and alexandrian. - (The Person and Teachings of Nestorius of Constantinople1 with a special reference to his Condemnation at the Council of Ephesus)

text.headline: Daniel the Indian scholar helps the translation works at the School of Edessa.
A letter of Courtesy written by the Patriach of Seleucia-Ctesiphon
text.text: "In the name of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. The stranger Yahb Alahā, through the mercies of Christ, the Catholicos Patriarch of the East asks your prayers and glory to Christ. He regularly prays to the Holy Father, the knowledgeable and active man, chosen by divine wisdom, who is seated on the throne of Simon Peter, entrusted to the Divine Secrets, keeper of the keys of the kingdom [of heaven], sun of the Christian nation, fifth evangelist, father of the fathers, the head of the bishops Mar Papa, may God bestow upon all of creation the shadow of his sanctity and He includes all the baptized people by his graces (… …) the stranger Yahb Alahā the keeper of the Church of the Lord Christ in the East and the Seat of saint Thomas, Saint Adai and Saint Mari he presents to You his greetings through our Lord ( … …) we inform Your holiness that the man who arrived to Your holy presence named Saʽd al-Dīn will inform You all our news and condition. Our greetings to all the fathers, monks who are vowed to the service (of God) and all who are by You (… …) It was written in July 1613 for the Greeks (=1302 A.D). May our Lord be with all of Us, Amen." - (Mar Yahballaha's letter to Pope Boniface VIII)

text.headline: A profession of Catholic faith
text.text: "We believe in the holy Roman chief pontiff and universal father of all believers in Christ, and confess that he is the successor of the blessed Peter, universal vicar of Jesus Christ over all the sons of the church from east and west; love and affection for whom is fixed in our hearts; and we owe obedience to him, and ask and implore his blessing, and are ready for all his commands, humbly asking and imploring his help in our necessity and tribulations in which we have now been for a long time and remain. And may the good father not turn away his face from us since we are all brothers in Christ and his sons through the true catholic faith." - (Mar Yahballaha's letter to Pope Benedict XI)
